results.title: Investigators: Divorce special
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Catherine Shirley
results.brief_description: This special edition of “The Investigators” looks at how two people can disentangle their lives when their marriage grinds to a halt. It is a consumer guide on how to ease the pain and loss of separation and includes useful hints on how to make a divorce less painful, if not more amicable.

results.title: Investigation of some hand motions
results.brief_description: An analysis of the following: 1. The time required to grasp machine screws from various types of bins. 2. The time required to position pins in bushings with bevelled holes. 3. The time required to position small blocks. Silent film with English intertitles.

results.title: Investigation of rape
results.brief_description: A training film for police and medical personnel which shows the procedures which they should follow in the investigation of rape. For women, an informative, educational film about an investigative procedure that they may have perceived with as much fear and apprehension as an attack itself.

results.title: Investigating hibernation: the golden-mantled ground squirrel
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Thomas Smith
results.brief_description: Investigates the underlying mechanism of hibernation and the concept of biological clocks. Squirrels still hibernate in the alien laboratory environment. The film shows clearly the arousal-increase in pulse rate, deeper breathing, shivering and contortions and the fully awakened normal temperature state.

results.title: Invest in a casting
results.creator_credit: British Information Services, Mottershaw Commercial Films, Alec Dalby and John Mottershaw
results.brief_description: Shows how the ancient lost-wax process for making castings is still used in investment casting. Follows the stages by which the ceramic die is prepared to receive the molten metal, the careful inspection of the die and the two different methods of casting. Demonstrates the whole process of casting and gives a series of examples of articles in common use made by investment casting.

results.title: Inversion (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau, College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota, Seymour Schuster and Jay Hines
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Geometric inversion is introduced and discussed to effect the solution of an apparently difficult problem involving the inscription of a chain of circles between two given circles, one inside the other. The final result, known as Steiner’s Porism, is forcefully illustrated in motion - “pop art” fashion.

results.title: Inventory. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Instructional Media, WPSX-TV, Penn State, Frank Wilson and Timothy Swartz
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Principles of accounting”.
Part two of inventory accounting, deals with the difference between the cost of inventory and the value of inventory. Cost is a fixed amount but value can change according to physical condition, market changes in demand and obsolescence. This program details ways of estimating this value for accounting purposes and how inventory records can be adjusted to accommodate fluctuations in value.

results.title: Inventors of thingumajigs
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Paul Larose and Raymond Garceau
results.brief_description: This beautiful, humorous and mad film introduces us to a very special breed of people whose rarefied ideas suffer occasional setbacks. Whatever the invention - comb-cleaner, panty-hose, snowmobile - these “inventors of thingumajigs” are a valuable natural resource who contribute much to society.

results.title: Inventors and inventions
results.brief_description: Invention is as old as the human race and just as there are many different types of inventions, there are also many different types of inventors. This video introduces a variety of inventors - including professionals, amateurs, artists, scientists, adults and teenagers. Also illustrated is the point that inventions don’t always have to be useful and can often lead to unpredictable results - but that the same care and attention to detail applies to all inventions, practical or otherwise. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Inventing the future
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, WGBH Productions and Nancy Linde
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The dream machine”.
Looks at the development of commercial computer companies and the technologies and innovations that emerged in the 1950’s and 60’s. The designers and engineers Eckert and Mauchly set up the first computer company in 1946 but failed as businessmen. In England, the computer industry was co-operatively led by Cambridge University and Lyons (a company famous for tea and cakes). IBM entered the arena in 1951 when they recognised the need to compete with computers. FORTRAN and COBOL languages were developed to overcome the time-consuming problem of programming computers. Technological developments fuelled by the requirements of NASA’S space program and the Pentagon’s involvement in the Cold War witnessed the production of electronic components that were quicker, smaller, cheaper, more efficient and reliable.
